file_system_forensic.title: File System Forensic Investigation
file_system_forensic.description: Investigate a seized disk using slack space analysis, file carving, and metadata forensics
file_system_forensic.introduction: A suspicious hard disk has been seized from an employee suspected of data exfiltration. The disk appears to have been wiped, but forensic analysis may reveal hidden evidence. You must follow proper forensic procedures: hash and image the original evidence, then investigate file system structures, analyze slack space for hidden data, recover deleted files through carving, identify disguised files using magic numbers, and reconstruct the timeline through metadata analysis.

customCommands.name: sha256sum
customCommands.description: Compute SHA256 hash of a file or device

validArgs./dev/sdb:
SHA256(/dev/sdb) = 3a7bd3e2360a3d29eea436fcfb7e44c735d117c42d1c1835420b6b9942dd4f1a
Hash computed successfully. Record this value for chain of custody.
validArgs./forensic/evidence.img:
SHA256(/forensic/evidence.img) = 3a7bd3e2360a3d29eea436fcfb7e44c735d117c42d1c1835420b6b9942dd4f1a
[✓] Hash MATCHES original evidence - Integrity verified!

customCommands.output:
Usage: sha256sum <file or device>
Computes cryptographic hash for forensic integrity verification.

customCommands.name: dd
customCommands.description: Create bit-by-bit forensic copy of a device

validArgs.if=/dev/sdb of=/forensic/evidence.img:
Creating forensic image...
  Source: /dev/sdb (500MB)
  Destination: /forensic/evidence.img
  Block size: 4096 bytes

122880+0 records in
122880+0 records out
503316480 bytes (500 MB) copied, 2.34 s, 215 MB/s

[✓] Forensic image created successfully at /forensic/evidence.img

customCommands.output:
Usage: dd if=<source> of=<destination>
Creates bit-by-bit copy for forensic analysis.

customCommands.name: fsstat
customCommands.description: Display file system statistics and structure information

validArgs./forensic/evidence.img:

--------------------------------------------

Free Inodes: 31254

CONTENT INFORMATION
--------------------------------------------

Block Range: 0 - 122879
Total Blocks: 122880
Free Blocks: 45231

[!] Note: Free blocks may contain recoverable deleted data

customCommands.output:
Usage: fsstat <image>
Displays detailed file system statistics for forensic analysis.

customCommands.name: blkcat
customCommands.description: Display contents of disk blocks including slack space

validArgs./forensic/evidence.img 2048:
Block 2048 - Slack Space Analysis
--------------------------------------------
Allocated to: readme.txt (partial)
File ends at offset: 89
Slack space begins at offset: 90

SLACK SPACE CONTENT (hex dump):
00000000: 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00  00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00  |................|

[i] No significant data found in this block's slack space.

customCommands.output:
Usage: blkcat <image> <block_number>
Displays raw block content including slack space for forensic analysis.

customCommands.name: foremost
customCommands.description: File carving tool to recover deleted files from disk images

validArgs.-t all -i /forensic/evidence.img -o /for:
Foremost version 1.5.7
Audit File: /forensic/recovered/audit.txt

Processing: /forensic/evidence.img
|████████████████████████████████████████| 100%

Recovered Files Summary:
--------------------------------------------
PDF files: 2
  - 00000156.pdf (confidential_report.pdf) - Deleted: 2026-10-15 04:12
  - 00000892.pdf (employee_data.pdf) - Deleted: 2026-10-14 23:45

ZIP files: 1
  - 00001024.zip (backup.zip) - Deleted: 2026-10-15 04:13

JPG files: 1
  - 00002048.jpg (screenshot.jpg) - Deleted: 2026-10-15 04:10

[✓] 4 files recovered to /forensic/recovered/

customCommands.output:
Usage: foremost -t <type> -i <image> -o <output_dir>
Carves files from disk images based on headers/footers.
Types: all, pdf, jpg, zip, doc, exe

customCommands.name: xxd
customCommands.description: Create hex dump of file to examine magic numbers and file signatures

validArgs./mnt/evidence/document.pdf:

00000010: 2030 206f 626a 0a3c 3c2f 5479 7065 2f43  .0.obj.<</Type/C

[✓] File signature matches extension: PDF document

customCommands.name: fls

Options: -r recursive, -d show deleted

tasks.title: Connect the seized hard disk
tasks.details: Click on the hard disk to physically connect it to the forensic workstation. This disk was seized from an employee suspected of data exfiltration.

onInteract.message:
Hard disk connected as /dev/sdb
Use 'lsblk' to display available devices

mountContent.suspicious.log:
2026-10-15 03:42:10 - Session started by jsmith
2026-10-15 03:45:12 - Unauthorized access attempt from 192.168.1.50
2026-10-15 03:45:34 - Successful login from 192.168.1.50
2026-10-15 03:47:21 - File accessed: /data/confidential_report.pdf
2026-10-15 03:48:55 - External USB device connected
2026-10-15 04:02:45 - File renamed: malware.exe -> image.jpg
2026-10-15 04:05:00 - Data transfer initiated
2026-10-15 04:12:00 - File deleted: confidential_report.pdf
2026-10-15 04:13:00 - File deleted: backup.zip
2026-10-15 04:15:22 - Session ended
mountContent.secret_notes.txt:
Meeting with contact at 10:00 PM
Drop location: parking garage B
Payment: 50k BTC
Target files secured

tasks.title: Identify the device partition
tasks.details: Use 'lsblk' to list connected block devices. Enter the partition name of the seized disk (e.g., sdb1).
tasks.hint: Look for the newly connected device in the lsblk output. The partition will have a number suffix.

tasks.title: Hash the original evidence
tasks.details: Before any analysis, compute a SHA256 hash of the original disk to establish integrity for chain of custody. Use 'sha256sum /dev/sdb'

tasks.title: Create forensic image
tasks.details: Never work on original evidence! Create a bit-by-bit forensic image using dd. Use 'dd if=/dev/sdb of=/forensic/evidence.img'

tasks.title: Verify image integrity
tasks.details: Hash the forensic image and verify it matches the original. Use 'sha256sum /forensic/evidence.img'

tasks.title: Analyze file system structure
tasks.details: Use 'fsstat /forensic/evidence.img' to examine the file system structure. What file system type is this disk formatted with? Enter only the file system name (lowercase).
tasks.hint: Look for 'File System Type:' in the fsstat output.

tasks.title: Determine total clusters
tasks.details: From the fsstat output, what is the total number of clusters (blocks) on this disk? Enter only the number.
tasks.hint: Look for 'Total Clusters:' or 'Total Blocks:' in the fsstat output.

tasks.title: Mount evidence read-only
tasks.details: Mount the forensic image in read-only mode to prevent accidental modification. Use 'mount -o ro /forensic/evidence.img /mnt/evidence'

tasks.title: List files including deleted
tasks.details: Use 'fls -rd /forensic/evidence.img' to list all files including deleted entries. How many deleted files are detected? Enter only the number.
tasks.hint: Count the entries marked with * (asterisk) in the fls output.

tasks.title: Investigate slack space
tasks.details: Deleted data may hide in slack space. Use 'blkcat /forensic/evidence.img 1024' to examine block 1024's slack space. What hidden message did you find? Enter the exact string.
tasks.hint: Look at the ASCII representation on the right side of the hex dump for readable text.

tasks.title: Recover deleted files
tasks.details: Use file carving to recover deleted files. Run 'foremost -t all -i /forensic/evidence.img -o /forensic/recovered'. What is the name of the first recovered PDF file that was deleted?
tasks.hint: Check the foremost output for recovered PDF files and their original names.

tasks.title: Determine deletion time
tasks.details: From the foremost recovery output, when was confidential_report.pdf deleted? Enter the timestamp in format: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM
tasks.hint: Look at the 'Deleted:' timestamp next to the file in the foremost output.

tasks.title: Analyze suspicious file magic bytes
tasks.details: The file 'image.jpg' looks suspicious. Use 'xxd /mnt/evidence/image.jpg' to examine its magic bytes. What is the TRUE file type? Enter: executable, pdf, zip, or jpeg
tasks.hint: Magic bytes 4D 5A (MZ) at the start indicate a Windows executable. Compare to expected JPEG magic: FF D8 FF.

tasks.title: Identify file owner
tasks.details: Use 'stat /mnt/evidence/suspicious.log' to examine file metadata. Who is the owner of this file? Enter only the username.
tasks.hint: Look for the 'Owner:' field in the stat output.

tasks.title: Determine last modification time
tasks.details: From the stat output of suspicious.log, what was the last modification time? Enter in format: HH:MM:SS
tasks.hint: Look for the 'Modify:' timestamp in the stat output.

tasks.title: Find attacker IP
tasks.details: Read the suspicious.log file using 'cat /mnt/evidence/suspicious.log'. What IP address successfully logged in to the system?
tasks.hint: Look for 'Successful login from' in the log file.

tasks.title: Identify evidence of data exfiltration
tasks.details: Review all evidence gathered. What file was renamed to disguise the malware? Enter the original filename.
tasks.hint: Check the suspicious.log for any 'File renamed' entries.

network_forensic.title: Network Forensic Investigation
network_forensic.description: Investigate a network breach using traffic analysis, log correlation, and protocol forensics to reconstruct an APT-style intrusion
network_forensic.introduction: At 02:30 AM, Nephilim Financial Services' Intrusion Detection System triggered a critical alert: anomalous encrypted outbound traffic was detected from their core server (10.0.0.5). The traffic pattern matched known DNS tunneling techniques used for data exfiltration. By the time the SOC team investigated, the suspicious connections had ceased — but the damage may already be done. Your forensic team has been called in to investigate the potential breach. Threat intelligence suggests this may be linked to APT-41, codenamed 'Shadow Pulse' — a group known for targeting financial institutions through brute-force entry, privilege escalation, and covert exfiltration channels. You must trace the intrusion path, preserve and analyze the network evidence, and reconstruct the full scope of the attack. Remember: hash before you analyze, work on copies, and follow every lead.

customCommands.name: trace-connection
customCommands.description: Trace signal to locate the compromised server
customCommands.output: [*] Initiating Network Traffic Analysis... [TARGET: Identify compromised server]
customCommands.onSuccess: Trace Complete. Compromised server identified: 10.0.0.5 (nephilim-srv). Use 'nmap 10.0.0.5' to enumerate services.

customCommands.name: nmap
customCommands.description: Network scanner — enumerate ports and services on target hosts

22/tcp  open  ssh      OpenSSH 7.6p1 Ubuntu 4ubuntu0.3
80/tcp  open  http     Apache httpd 2.4.29
443/tcp open  https    Apache httpd 2.4.29 (SSL)

OS: Ubuntu 18.04 LTS
Uptime: 127 days

[!] VULNERABILITY: OpenSSH 7.6p1 is outdated and vulnerable to user enumeration (CVE-2018-15473)
[!] SSH allows password authentication — potential brute-force vector

443/tcp open  ssl/http Apache httpd 2.4.29 ((Ubuntu))

Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel

Usage: nmap [options] <target IP>
Network exploration tool and port scanner.
Options: -sV (version detection), -sC (default scripts)

customCommands.name: sha256sum

Computing hashes for chain of custody...

SHA256(/var/log/network/auth.log)     = a1b2c3d4e5f6a7b8c9d0e1f2a3b4c5d6e7f8a9b0c1d2e3f4a5b6c7d8e9f0a1b2
SHA256(/var/log/network/firewall.log) = b2c3d4e5f6a7b8c9d0e1f2a3b4c5d6e7f8a9b0c1d2e3f4a5b6c7d8e9f0a1b2c3
SHA256(/var/log/network/access.log)   = c3d4e5f6a7b8c9d0e1f2a3b4c5d6e7f8a9b0c1d2e3f4a5b6c7d8e9f0a1b2c3d4
SHA256(/var/log/network/capture.pcap) = d4e5f6a7b8c9d0e1f2a3b4c5d6e7f8a9b0c1d2e3f4a5b6c7d8e9f0a1b2c3d4e5

customCommands.name: tcpdump
customCommands.description: Packet analyzer — read and filter network capture files
customCommands.output:
Usage: tcpdump -r <pcap_file> [filter]
Read and analyze packet capture files.
Filters: host <ip>, port <port>, tcp, udp

customCommands.name: tshark
customCommands.description: Terminal-based Wireshark — deep packet inspection and protocol analysis

tasks.title: Trace the suspicious signal
tasks.details: The IDS detected anomalous traffic from an internal server. Use 'trace-connection' to locate the compromised machine.

tasks.title: Enumerate target services
tasks.details: The compromised server is at 10.0.0.5. Use 'nmap 10.0.0.5' to discover what services are running and identify potential vulnerabilities.

tasks.title: Identify the exploited service
tasks.details: From the nmap scan results, which service was flagged as vulnerable and likely used as the entry point? Enter only the service name (lowercase).
tasks.hint: Look at the nmap output — which service shows a specific vulnerability CVE? OpenSSH 7.6p1 is known to be outdated and exploitable.

tasks.title: Connect to the compromised server
tasks.details: Click on the server to establish a secure connection and access the log files for forensic analysis.

onInteract.message:
Connected to nephilim-srv (10.0.0.5) via forensic SSH session
Evidence logs available at /var/log/network
Use 'ls /var/log/network' to list available evidence files

mountContent.auth.log:
Oct 15 02:15:33 nephilim-srv sshd[2401]: Failed password for admin from 192.168.1.50 port 44231 ssh2
Oct 15 02:15:36 nephilim-srv sshd[2401]: Failed password for admin from 192.168.1.50 port 44231 ssh2
Oct 15 02:15:40 nephilim-srv sshd[2401]: Failed password for admin from 192.168.1.50 port 44231 ssh2
Oct 15 02:15:44 nephilim-srv sshd[2401]: Failed password for admin from 192.168.1.50 port 44231 ssh2
Oct 15 02:15:48 nephilim-srv sshd[2401]: Failed password for admin from 192.168.1.50 port 44231 ssh2
Oct 15 02:15:53 nephilim-srv sshd[2401]: Accepted password for admin from 192.168.1.50 port 44231 ssh2
Oct 15 02:15:53 nephilim-srv sshd[2401]: pam_unix(sshd:session): session opened for user admin
Oct 15 02:16:05 nephilim-srv sudo: admin : TTY=pts/0 ; PWD=/home/admin ; USER=root ; COMMAND=/bin/bash
Oct 15 02:18:12 nephilim-srv sshd[2455]: Accepted publickey for svc_backup from 10.0.0.12 port 55021 ssh2
Oct 15 02:18:12 nephilim-srv sshd[2455]: pam_unix(sshd:session): session opened for user svc_backup
Oct 15 02:30:44 nephilim-srv sshd[2401]: pam_unix(sshd:session): session closed for user admin
mountContent.capture.pcap:
[Binary packet capture — 24MB]
Use tcpdump or tshark to analyze this file.
1423 packets captured from nephilim-srv eth0 interface.
Capture period: Oct 15 02:10:00 — Oct 15 04:35:00

tasks.title: Hash evidence for chain of custody
tasks.details: Before any analysis, compute SHA256 hashes of all evidence files to document their integrity. Use 'sha256sum /var/log/network/*'

tasks.title: Create forensic working copies
tasks.details: Never analyze original evidence directly. Create working copies using 'cp -r /var/log/network /forensic/logs'

tasks.title: Identify the attacker's IP address
tasks.details: Analyze the authentication logs at '/forensic/logs/auth.log'. What IP address was used to perform the SSH brute-force attack and ultimately gain access?
tasks.hint: Use 'cat /forensic/logs/auth.log' or 'grep "Failed password" /forensic/logs/auth.log'. The same IP appears in both failed and successful login attempts.

tasks.title: Count the brute-force attempts
tasks.details: How many failed SSH login attempts were recorded before the attacker gained access? Enter only the number.
tasks.hint: Use 'grep "Failed password" /forensic/logs/auth.log' to filter only the failed attempts, then count the matching lines.

tasks.title: Detect the reverse shell
tasks.details: After gaining SSH access, the attacker established a reverse shell back to their machine. Analyze the firewall logs at '/forensic/logs/firewall.log' to find the outbound connection. What port did the reverse shell connect to? Enter only the port number.
tasks.hint: Look in firewall.log for outbound connections FROM the server (10.0.0.5) TO the attacker's IP (192.168.1.50) on an unusual port. Port 4444 is a classic reverse shell port often used by Metasploit.

tasks.title: Identify lateral movement
tasks.details: Attackers often pivot through compromised machines. Analyze the firewall and auth logs — which internal server did the attacker move to after compromising nephilim-srv? Enter the IP address.
tasks.hint: In firewall.log, look for SSH connections FROM 10.0.0.5 TO other internal IP addresses. Cross-reference with auth.log — the 'svc_backup' account login provides a clue.

tasks.title: Analyze DNS exfiltration traffic
tasks.details: The IDS flagged suspicious DNS traffic. Use tshark to filter DNS queries from the packet capture: 'tshark -r /forensic/logs/capture.pcap -Y dns'
tasks.hint: Run the tshark command exactly as shown. DNS tunneling hides data inside DNS query subdomains — the Base32-encoded strings before the domain name are the stolen data.

tasks.title: Identify the C2 exfiltration domain
tasks.details: The tshark output reveals DNS tunneling activity. What domain name is being used as the exfiltration channel? Enter the full domain (e.g., subdomain.example.com).
tasks.hint: Look at the DNS queries in the tshark output. The encoded subdomains all share a common parent domain — that domain is the C2 exfiltration channel. It contains the threat group's name.

tasks.title: Determine what data was exfiltrated
tasks.details: The attacker accessed the web application before exfiltrating data. Review the web server access logs at '/forensic/logs/access.log'. What type of data did they download (look for the largest response)? Enter only the data type keyword from the URL path.
tasks.hint: Use 'cat /forensic/logs/access.log' and look for the HTTP request with the largest response size (in bytes). The URL path '/api/v1/clients?format=csv' with a 2.3MB response reveals what was stolen.

tasks.title: Establish the initial compromise time
tasks.details: Based on all evidence collected, when did the attack begin? Enter the timestamp of the first brute-force attempt in HH:MM format.
tasks.hint: The attack timeline starts with the earliest malicious event. Look at the first 'Failed password' entry in auth.log for the exact time (HH:MM format).

memory_forensic.title: Memory Forensic Investigation
memory_forensic.description: Analyze a live RAM dump to uncover a fileless malware attack using Volatility
memory_forensic.introduction: OPERATION PHANTOM THREAD — Meridian Capital Partners, a quantitative trading firm, detected unauthorized trades on their platform. The SOC team captured a live 8GB memory dump from the primary trading workstation (WKS-TRADE-07) using LiME before the system was shut down. Initial disk forensics found NO malware artifacts — this is a fileless attack operating entirely in memory. You must analyze the RAM dump using Volatility to uncover the attack chain, identify injected processes, and determine what was stolen.

customCommands.name: sha256sum
customCommands.description: Compute SHA256 hash of a file or device

validArgs./dev/sdc:
SHA256(/dev/sdc) = a1b2c3d4e5f6a7b8c9d0e1f2a3b4c5d6e7f8a9b0c1d2e3f4a5b6c7d8e9f0a1b2

[✓] Hash computed successfully.
[!] Record this value — it proves the memory dump has not been modified.

customCommands.output:
Usage: sha256sum <file or device>
Computes cryptographic hash for forensic integrity verification.

customCommands.name: dd
customCommands.description: Create bit-by-bit forensic copy of a device

  Destination: /forensic/memdump.img
  Block size: 4096 bytes

2097152+0 records in
2097152+0 records out
8589934592 bytes (8.6 GB) copied, 45.2 s, 190 MB/s

[✓] Memory dump copy created at /forensic/memdump.img
[!] Original evidence on /dev/sdc preserved.

tasks.title: Connect the HD with memory dump
tasks.details: The memory dump from workstation WKS-TRADE-07 has been delivered on a hard disk. Click on the hard disk to connect it to the forensic workstation.

onInteract.message:
Device connected as /dev/sdc
Contains 8GB RAM dump from WKS-TRADE-07 (Meridian Capital Partners)

mountContent.memory.dmp:
[Binary memory dump - 8GB]
Windows 10 Build 19041 x64 memory image
Captured: 2024-11-22 14:30:00 UTC via LiME
Source: WKS-TRADE-07 (10.10.15.22)
mountContent.incident_report.txt:
INCIDENT RESPONSE REPORT — CONFIDENTIAL
========================================
Case: MCP-IR-2024-1122
Organization: Meridian Capital Partners
Analyst: SOC Team Lead
Date: 2024-11-22

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
At approximately 14:15 UTC, the SOC detected anomalous outbound HTTPS
traffic from workstation WKS-TRADE-07 (10.10.15.22). The trading desk
reported that user 'trader1' received a spear-phishing email at
approximately 13:45 UTC containing a malicious Excel attachment:
Q3_Projections_FINAL.xlsm

INITIAL FINDINGS
- Spear-phishing email delivered to trader1@meridian-capital.com
- Malicious macro in Excel file executed PowerShell download cradle
- No malware artifacts found on disk (fileless attack)
- Memory dump captured at 14:30 UTC using LiME before system shutdown
- Suspicious outbound connections to unknown IP detected by IDS

AFFECTED SYSTEMS
- WKS-TRADE-07 (10.10.15.22) — Primary trading workstation
- User account: MERIDIAN\trader1

PRIORITY: CRITICAL
Potential credential theft and unauthorized trading access.
mountContent.baseline_processes.txt:
BASELINE PROCESSES — WKS-TRADE-07
==================================
Normal running processes (captured 2024-11-01 during routine audit):

System (PID 4)                  — Windows kernel
smss.exe (PID ~300-400)         — Session Manager
csrss.exe (PID ~400-500)        — Client/Server Runtime
wininit.exe (PID ~500-600)      — Windows Init
services.exe (PID ~600-700)     — Service Control Manager
lsass.exe (PID ~600-700)        — Local Security Authority
svchost.exe (multiple)          — Service Host (typical: 6-10 threads)
explorer.exe (PID ~2000-2500)   — Windows Explorer
chrome.exe (PID varies)         — Google Chrome
TradingApp.exe (PID varies)     — MCP Trading Platform
RuntimeBroker.exe (PID varies)  — Runtime Broker

NOTES:
[!] svchost.exe instances typically have 6-10 threads each.
[!] Any svchost.exe with >12 threads should be investigated.
[!] powershell.exe is NOT expected during normal trading operations.
[!] cmd.exe should not be spawned by powershell.exe.
mountContent.registry_hives.txt:
Windows Registry Analysis
==========================
Extracted registry hives from memory dump

HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run
  - SecurityHealthSystray : C:\Windows\System32\SecurityHealthSystray.exe     [LEGITIMATE]
  - OneDrive              : C:\Users\trader1\AppData\Local\Microsoft\OneDrive\OneDrive.exe  [LEGITIMATE]
  - WindowsDefender       : rundll32.exe C:\Users\trader1\AppData\Local\Temp\msupdate.dll,DllRegisterServer  [SUSPICIOUS]

HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run
  - ChromeUpdater : powershell.exe -nop -w hidden -ep bypass -enc UwB0AGEAcgB0AC0AUwBsAGUAZQBwACAAMwAwADsASQBFAFgA...  [MALICIOUS]

HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services
  - SysHealthMonitor (Display: System Health Monitor Service)
    ImagePath: C:\Windows\Temp\syshealth.exe
    Start: 2 (Automatic)
    [!] SUSPICIOUS: Unknown service — not in Windows baseline

[!] 3 persistence mechanisms detected:
    1. HKCU Run key 'ChromeUpdater' — hidden PowerShell with encoded command
    2. HKLM Run key 'WindowsDefender' — loads msupdate.dll via rundll32
    3. Service 'SysHealthMonitor' — unknown executable in Windows\Temp

tasks.title: Verify connected devices
tasks.details: Use 'lsblk' to confirm the memory dump device is properly connected and identify its designation.

tasks.title: Verify dump integrity
tasks.details: Before any analysis, compute the SHA256 hash of the memory dump to establish evidence integrity. Use 'sha256sum /dev/sdc'.

tasks.title: Create forensic working copy
tasks.details: Create a bit-by-bit forensic copy of the memory dump for analysis. Use 'dd if=/dev/sdc of=/forensic/memdump.img' to preserve the original evidence.

tasks.title: Mount the forensic copy
tasks.details: Never work directly on the original evidence. Mount your forensic copy for analysis using 'mount /forensic/memdump.img /mnt/memdump'. All subsequent analysis will be performed on this copy.

tasks.title: Identify the operating system profile
tasks.details: Use 'vol-imageinfo /forensic/memdump.img' to determine the OS profile of the captured system. What is the suggested Volatility profile name? Enter the exact profile string (e.g., Win7SP1x64).
tasks.hint: Run 'vol-imageinfo /forensic/memdump.img' and look at the 'Suggested Profile(s)' line. The answer is the profile name shown there.

tasks.title: Find the suspicious process
tasks.details: List all running processes using 'vol-pslist /forensic/memdump.img'. Compare the output with 'cat /mnt/memdump/baseline_processes.txt' to identify anomalies. Which svchost.exe PID has an unusually high thread count? Enter only the PID number.
tasks.hint: Normal svchost.exe instances have 6-10 threads (see baseline_processes.txt). One svchost.exe in the vol-pslist output has 15 threads and started much later than the others (13:48 vs 08:00). Its PID is the answer.

tasks.title: Identify the C2 server
tasks.details: Use 'vol-netscan /forensic/memdump.img' to examine active network connections. What IP address is the compromised svchost.exe (PID 3472) communicating with? Enter only the IP address.
tasks.hint: In the vol-netscan output, look for ESTABLISHED connections from PID 3472. It connects to the same foreign IP on two ports (443 and 8443). That IP is also used by powershell.exe (PID 4012) on port 4444.

tasks.title: Decrypt obfuscated memory regions
tasks.details: The memory dump contains encrypted/obfuscated payloads that must be decrypted before Volatility can fully analyze them. Use 'find-malware' to decrypt the protected memory regions.

tasks.title: Detect the code injection technique
tasks.details: Run 'vol-malfind /forensic/memdump.img' to scan for injected code. What injection technique was used to compromise svchost.exe (PID 3472)? Enter the technique name in lowercase.
tasks.hint: The vol-malfind output for PID 3472 shows an injected PE (MZ header) with PAGE_EXECUTE_READWRITE protection. The analysis line states the specific injection technique used — it involves replacing the legitimate process content.

tasks.title: Identify the malicious module
tasks.details: Examine the loaded DLLs of the suspicious svchost.exe process using 'vol-dlllist /forensic/memdump.img -p 3472'. What is the filename of the suspicious DLL loaded from an unusual path? Enter only the filename with extension.
tasks.hint: All legitimate DLLs are loaded from C:\Windows\System32\. One DLL is loaded from C:\Users\trader1\AppData\Local\Temp\ — that is not a standard DLL path. Its name mimics a Windows update component.

tasks.title: Determine the attack vector
tasks.details: Review the incident response report at '/mnt/memdump/incident_report.txt'. What was the exact filename of the malicious attachment used in the spear-phishing attack? Enter the complete filename with extension.
tasks.hint: Use 'cat' to read the report. The Executive Summary section mentions a malicious Excel attachment received via spear-phishing.

tasks.title: Identify the initial payload method
tasks.details: The vol-malfind output for powershell.exe (PID 4012) shows the decoded attack script. What .NET method did the PowerShell download cradle use to fetch the second-stage payload? Enter the method name only (one word, lowercase).
tasks.hint: Look at the vol-malfind output for PID 4012. The decoded hex shows 'IEX (New-Object System.Net.WebClient).<method>(...)'. The method name is how the script downloads the payload from the C2 server.

tasks.title: Find the persistence mechanism
tasks.details: Examine the extracted registry hives at '/mnt/memdump/registry_hives.txt'. The attacker set up multiple persistence mechanisms. What is the name of the registry Run key that executes a hidden PowerShell command? Enter only the key name.
tasks.hint: Use 'cat /mnt/memdump/registry_hives.txt' and look under HKCU\...\CurrentVersion\Run. One entry is marked [MALICIOUS] and runs PowerShell with hidden window and encoded command. The key name disguises itself as a legitimate browser updater.

tasks.title: Establish the initial compromise time
tasks.details: Based on all evidence collected, determine when the initial compromise occurred. Cross-reference the vol-pslist process start times to find when the attacker's PowerShell download cradle first executed. Enter the time in HH:MM format.
tasks.hint: The attack chain starts with powershell.exe (PID 4012) — this is the macro-triggered download cradle. Its start time in vol-pslist shows exactly when the malicious Excel macro executed. Look for the Start column for PID 4012.
